There is a lot of excitement about the comment. However, it ignores the fact that work has always changed â€“ and inefficient professions have ceased to exist over time. A few thoughts on this.

It is hard to imagine today, but when street lamps were still powered by gas, there was a profession called lamp lighter. Obviously, this is no longer necessary today.

And the same thing will happen â€“ only on a much larger scale â€“ to numerous professions in the near future. Apart from truly specialised professionals, simple white-collar jobs will almost certainly be decimated at first, because one person acting as the conductor of numerous agents will be completely replaced in the future.

And that's not a bad thing! We should welcome the fact that AI is taking on tedious work for us. What's more, we will have more free time to devote to creative activities; people will seek out new challenges or social problems and strive to find solutions. Humans are creative, active beings. I am convinced that boredom will not set in. And even if, as in Star Trek, people now see their task as exploring the unknown.

What people are rightly concerned about, however, is the loss of their income. This concern is indeed justified. And a solution is indeed needed. But that is a social issue that can be resolved. All other concerns are unfounded.

Even if 99% of music or films are generated by AI in the future, people will still get out their guitars and sing songs together with their friends, because humans are social beings and enjoy singing and dancing. The only concern is the marketing of art and culture in terms of generating income. And again, this concern is indeed justified and must be resolved.

Otherwise, we should welcome, promote and accelerate the technological revolution. Because we cannot oppose it anyway.

Here are two very important charts about the current AI boom. 

Chart 1: Distribution Matters

Open AI is still the clear leader but, interestingly, they are loosing percentage share as the market grows. This is normal for a category leader but itâ€™s curious who they are losing share to. Itâ€™s not really to other startups but incumbents with existing, massive distribution. This means that Google has a huge runway ahead of itself as their models and services become better. It also means that when/if Meta gets their act together, they will be able to gain share quickly. Lastly, it likely means that xAI will need to license Grok aggressively OR acquire existing distribution for their models - Snapchat, Pinterest etc.

Chart 2: Coding Agents are Slopware App-crappers

It should be concerning that this category is shrinking. I think the reason why is obvious but we arenâ€™t allowed to talk about it. 

The reason is vibe coding is a joke. 

It is deeply unserious and these tools arenâ€™t delivering when they encounter real world complexity (building quick demos isnâ€™t complex) in any meaningful enterprise. 

Hence people try, pay, churn. This trend is not good.

AI 2026: Schrittweisers analysis

Julian Schrittweiser has provided a very catchy but at the same time plausible outlook for AI over the next two years.

In short: instead of listening to all the different "experts," we should just look at the data. METR has shown that the amount of work that AI can perform virtually independently is increasing exponentially; by mid-2026, AI models will be able to work an entire day (8 hours) on their own.

The latest benchmark from OpenAI shows that even relatively old models (old meaning two months old) can already perform nearly 50% of the tasks of a skilled worker with around 14 years of work experience (real-world-task benchmark)

In short, 2026 will see a major shift in the world of work, as AI models will be able to match the expertise of skilled workers in real-world tasks and work independently for eight hours. It is difficult to predict how this will develop by 2027. 

Highly recommend your read his blogarticle

This may be the biggest AI/health breakthrough of the year 

New AI can cook up cures for cancer and heals at the cellular level.

Harvard scientists just developed a potential game changer for medicine: PDGrapher, a free AI model that doesnâ€™t just find drug targets, it figures out treatments that reverse disease states in cells.

"The tool identifies the best single or combined targets for treatments that correct the disease process."

Instead of the old trial and error method of testing one protein at a time, PDGrapher uses graph neural networks to map the entire cellular network, pinpoint the key drivers of disease, and suggest the best single or combo treatments to restore health.

Tested on 19 datasets across 11 cancers, it rediscovered known drug targets, uncovered new ones like KDR and TOP2A, and outperformed other AI tools with up to 35% better accuracy and 25Ã— faster results.

What it means:

faster drug discovery, 
smarter personalized medicine,  
breakthroughs for hard to treat diseases like cancer, Parkinsonâ€™s, and Alzheimerâ€™s. From just one AI tool.

You can now visually edit any part of your web app just by clicking an element and describing the change. No code necessaryâ€”just click, describe, and see your updates instantly in preview mode.

Sam Altman with Vinod Khosla says that AI models will keep improving across every dimension, smarter, cheaper, more multimodal, better reasoning, roughly 10x per year, and the smartest move is to simply assume that progress and build on it.

Big AI/science news 

New amazing AI from Google can write expert level science software, and can do it 100x - 1000x faster than humans.

AI science acceleration

Researchers developed an AI system that can write expert level scientific software to speed up discoveries. 

It

OpenAI CEO, Sam Altman:

Over the next 18 months, we could go from "10 to 100", an even bigger leap than the "1 to 10" since the ChatGPT launch

But the shock will feel smaller.

People now expect extraordinary progress, even if the real-world impact is far greater

Microsoft is moving away from OpenAI for Office 365 and bringing Anthropic on board. 

Claude models will be used for certain Copilot features in Word, Excel, and PowerPoint in the futureâ€”especially where they perform better according to internal tests, such as in spreadsheet

Sam Altman with Vinod Khosla says that the real shock was the 0â†’1 leap with ChatGPT; the next jumps (1â†’10 and 10â†’100) will have bigger impact, but feel less surprising because the astonishing is now expected.

OpenAI is partnering with an unnamed startup to produce Critterz, a feature-length animated film generated largely with its own AI tools. 

The team aims to premiere the movie at the 2026 Cannes Film Festival, showcasing how generative AI can slash both cost and production time

Roman Yampolskiy, a professor of computer science and pioneer in the field of AI safety, claimed in a podcast that by 2030, around 99% of all jobs could be automated by AI â€“ from software jobs to physical activities. He believes that AGI could become a reality as early as 2027 â€“ and then render almost all jobs obsolete within five years.

I don't find his theories convincing that we will ultimately end up at 99%. But more and more voices are joining in, and the first empirical data suggests that Dario Amodei is right and that we will see serious shifts in the entry-level sector and the first major impacts on the labor market due to AI.

I will conduct a major study in the coming weeks, compile all the data, and see what empirical research has to say on the matter.

It's coming. More and more reports about the coming unemployment are being published.

"The Gerald Huff Fund for Humanity today released Impact of AI on Workers in the United States,  a groundbreaking analysis revealing that artificial intelligence is on  track to disrupt roughly one in four U.S. jobs by 2028. The report warns  that we are entering an economic upheaval on a scale seen only once a  century, requiring bold policy responses to protect families and  communities."

- Job Disruption â€“ 45.3 million jobs are at risk of being disrupted by AI by 2028.

- Shift in Automation â€“ AI is advancing into white-collar,  cognitive, and administrative work, from HR and finance to customer  service, education, and healthcare, not just physical labor.

- Hardest-Hit Sectors â€“ Retail, Finance, Education, and Real Estate face the highest levels of expected disruptions.

- Skill Protection â€“ Human-centric skills such as empathy, adaptability, and judgment will be the strongest defense against automation.

- Retraining Limits â€“ Historical trends show that retraining alone often leads to lower wages and long-term income loss.

I predict AGI and ASI will be achieved by the end of 2026.

Since these terms lack precise definitions, I define Artificial General Intelligence as the point when AI begins replacing all human workers - the human-to-AI transition point.

Artificial Super Intelligence can be defined as the point when AI matches the intelligence of the smartest humans, and becomes capable of innovation.

People tend to develop unique insights and innovative ideas above an IQ of 130.

By early 2026, AI will reach an IQ of 130, equal to the top 2% of humans.

By the end of 2026, it will reach an IQ of 150, the level of the top 0.04% of humans.

We are already seeing signs of insight from AI at an IQ of 123. This will improve rapidly over the next year.

Significant job disruption and AI-driven innovation could emerge within a year.

I define Artificial Universal Intelligence (AUI) as AIâ€™s ultimate limit of knowledge (kMAX) and intelligence (gMAX), which I project will be reached by 2029.

However, AIâ€™s practical impact will arrive much earlier, since it does not need to reach gMAX to replace human jobs or begin solving major problems.

The most exponential development is probably not the one you want.

AI data centers will require massive power increases - from 4 GW in 2024 to an estimated 123 GW by 2035 (30x growth). 

For comparison, 123 GW:
-Could supply approximately 135 million American households
-This corresponds to roughly all households in Germany, France, and Spain combined

Some future data center campuses could consume 5 GW - enough to power 5 million homes.
